awd_titl_txt: Conference: 21st International Conference on Random Structures & Algorithms
awd_abstract_narration:
The 21st International Conference on Random Structures & Algorithms will take place at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, June 12 - 16, 2023. The conference will feature 8 plenary lectures by leading researchers in the field as well as contributed talks.

This is a biennial meeting, initiated in 1983 by the Faculty of Mathematics, Adam Mickiewicz University, in Poznan, Poland.  The aims of these conferences are to present recent research results and to identify and explore directions for further research in random discrete structures, randomized algorithms, and broad areas of application of probabilistic methods in discrete mathematics, computer science, and related fields. For more information see the conference web page: https://rsa.math.cmu.edu/RSA2023/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This grant provided partial support for the 21st International Conference on Random Structures & Algorithms. This conferences was held June 12-16, 2023, at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh.

Random Structures & Algorithms is a biennial meeting, initiated in 1983 by the Faculty of Mathematics, Adam Mickiewicz University, in Poznan, Poland. The aims of these conferences are to present recent research results and to identify and explore directions for further research in random discrete structures, randomized algorithms and broad areas of applications of probabilistic methods in discrete mathematics and computer science. 

The scientific centerpiece of the meeting was provided by a series of 50 minute lectures delivered by the following plenary speakers.

Noga Alon, Princeton University

Annika Heckel, Uppsala University

Jeff Kahn, Rutgers University

Sam Mattheus, University of California, San Diego

Richard Montgomery, University of Warwick

Jinyoung Park, New York University

Julian Sahasrabudhe, University of Cambridge

Joel Spencer, New York University

Eric Vigoda, University of California, Santa Barbara

Two of these speakers, namely Sam Mattheus and Julian Sahasrabuhde, were added to the list of speakers in the weeks leading up to the meeting. Wewere delighted to be able to include them as they had recently produced remarkable breakthroughs in graph Ramsey Theory.

In addition to these plenary lectures, nearly 80 shorter contributed talks were delivered by conference participants. The full list of speakers, together with talk titles and talk abstracts is available at the conference website which will be maintained indefinately. 

A significant proportion of the participants in the conference were students or recent PhDs. Thus, the conference provided an excellent venue for the further development of the workforce in mathematics.


Last Modified: 05/30/2024
Modified by: Tom A Bohman
